page.title: 21Staplehurst - Businesses & Services - Continuity & Change
page.content: Here are some examples of continuity and change in local businesses and services since the 1980s. They are drawn from research by Christopher Sharp, a Time2Give volunteer at Staplehurst Library: Staplehurst Library is still in the same premises in the Parade, but was refurbished in 2006. As well as giving free access to books, Staplehurst Library has a much expanded range of services and activities: Children's activities include baby rhyme time, storytime and craft sessions. The library lends DVDs and audio material, for a small charge. There is free access to computers with internet facilities. There is support for local reading groups and opportunities to volunteer, eg. as a computer buddy. Nat West is now the only bank in the Parade. The Supermarket, formerly Liptons, then Londis, is now a Spar. The village now has four pubs rather than six. They are The Pride of Kent, The Bell, The King's Head & The Railway Tavern. The Post Office in the High St survived a temporary closure in 2010. However, there is no longer a Post Office outlet in Station Rd. The Bower Dental Service, in the High St is an example of a practice that was established in 1986. Peter Jones, The Optician, also in the High St, is an example of long-running local business, (established in neighbouring Cranbrook in 1978.) In September this year, D.K. Holdings Ltd and Sainsbury's used the Youth Club to exhibit proposals to provide a new bespoke factory for D.K. Holdings and a new Sainsbury's store on the Station Rd industrial estate. There is no doubt that these proposals could be a major influence in the further development of Staplehurst. Staplehurst continues to flourish in 2011. Here's to the next 25 years in 2036!
